stream_context.summary: Kaze and Zeina focus on finishing the first mission of Course 11, an oil-rig level where Mario sabotages Koopas. Work centered on baby-penguin animations, a breakable glass set-piece, and modeling a Wiggler foreman. Kaze also demoed his side-project “Only Up 64,” scheduled to release the next day.

development_findings.summary: “Only Up 64” is complete: a single 28.5-minute vertical course that runs at 60 FPS on real N64 hardware and releases tomorrow.
development_findings.quote: It’s 28.5 minutes just to get to the top… yes, it works on real hardware; it even hits 60 FPS.

development_findings.summary: The hack contains anti-save-state code that detects sudden memory shifts/EPROM desyncs and locks player input with a “no cheating” message.
development_findings.quote: I detect whether the EPROM desyncs from the memory state; it just says no cheating and you’re done.

development_findings.summary: Course 11 mission premise: Mario must prank four groups of Bowser’s crew; each prank only triggers once and feeds into a supervising Wiggler’s anger.
development_findings.quote: The idea is that you mess with a bunch of NPCs and you just mess with everyone once.

development_findings.summary: Glass-shatter set-piece: chose two pre-cut pieces with hard-coded motion to mimic physics, avoiding dozens of small shards for performance.
development_findings.quote: We’re just going to fake it so we don’t actually have to write a physics simulation.

development_findings.summary: Abandoned an oil-barrel slip gag for being too cryptic; the mission will ship with only four pranks.
development_findings.quote: Kicking the oil barrel is not intuitive and also that’s not very funny… I’m not really a fan of that.

development_findings.summary: Designed a Wiggler foreman NPC: wears boots and tiny helmets, grows angrier after each prank, then runs off and spawns the star.
development_findings.quote: He has to be a Wiggler because he gets angry… after you did everything he’ll run off and spawn a star.

development_findings.summary: Secret Wing Cap will be hidden on the crane; soft invisible walls will stop players flying into unloaded zones.
development_findings.quote: Alright, let’s add a Wing Cap… the only invisible wall we need is here.

development_findings.summary: Strict polygon budget: Wiggler was reduced from ~1,000 to ~670 triangles by deleting helmet interiors and limiting segments.
development_findings.quote: A thousand triangles is too much; can’t waste my polygon budget like that.

development_findings.summary: Performance philosophy: prefers static over dynamic collision, new sine/cosine approximations, plans to re-export levels when Fast64 tools improve.
development_findings.quote: You know what else makes a sub run like? Using static collision instead of dynamic.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works remotely for Gears for Breakfast, values work-from-home culture, and is bound by an NDA on their new game.
context_findings.quote: Working at Gears is super chill… I don’t want to break my NDA by accident.

context_findings.summary: Strong preference for mouse-plus-controller control schemes and disdain for d-pads and 2D platformers.
context_findings.quote: Controller + mouse is the future… I can’t stand games that have limited directions.

context_findings.summary: Critiques unpaid lunch breaks in the U.S. and jokes about free hardware sent by Chinese manufacturers.
context_findings.quote: You go on lunch break, you’re forced to be at work and they don’t pay you for it—that’s fucked up.

context_findings.summary: Expresses excitement when the first Course 11 star nears completion, and mild frustration with rigging/lighting issues.

biobak.summary: Absent from stream; Kaze jokes about assigning him an Andrew Tate meme ‘theme song.’
biobak.quote: What if we just start calling this the Biobak theme song and then pull up Andrew Tate in front of a Bugatti?

badub.summary: Composing the main track for Course 11; early draft shared on stream and generally well-received.
badub.quote: Oh yeah, you guys haven’t heard it yet but Badub made a soundtrack for this level… I like a lot of the ideas.

zeina.summary: Handling all baby-penguin animations (walk, waddle, slide, get-up) and will animate the Wiggler foreman.
zeina.quote: There are no existing animations—she’s making all of them right now.

zeina.summary: Provides occasional chat moderation and lighthearted banter with Kaze (they are spouses).

key_stories.title: Anti-Save-State Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze didn’t want players to trivialize “Only Up 64,” so he devised a way to disable save-state cheating.
key_stories.challenge: Players normally bypass hard hacks with emulator save-states.
key_stories.process: Wrote code to detect EPROM/memory mismatches and instantly lock controls with a warning.
key_stories.outcome: Game now forces legitimate play; Kaze predicts fewer than ten people will finish it legitimately.
key_stories.key_quote: If a ROM hack is difficult you just save state, but mine just says no cheating and you’re done.

key_stories.title: Faking Glass Physics
key_stories.summary: Needed a dramatic glass-shatter without taxing the N64.
key_stories.challenge: True physics and many shards would bust the triangle and object budgets.
key_stories.process: Split the pane into two pre-cut models, hard-coded their fall and rotation, and timed Koopas’ sad reaction.
key_stories.outcome: Set-piece looks convincing and keeps performance in budget.
key_stories.key_quote: We’re just going to fake it so we don’t have to write a physics simulation.

key_stories.title: Cutting the Oil-Barrel Gag
key_stories.summary: An oil-slick prank was removed for clarity and pacing.
key_stories.challenge: Original idea—kick a leaking barrel so a Koopa slips—tested as too cryptic and not funny enough.
key_stories.process: Kaze discussed alternatives on stream and ultimately dropped the fifth prank entirely.
key_stories.outcome: Mission now features four clearer trolls; dev time redirected to other elements.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s just so unintuitive. I don’t think it’s worth it.

key_stories.title: Designing the Wiggler Foreman
key_stories.summary: A new NPC will judge the player’s sabotage.
key_stories.challenge: Needs a multi-segment model with expressive anger but must respect N64 limits.
key_stories.process: Kit-bashed from baby-Wiggler, added boots and helmets, trimmed polygons, planned anger logic and path to despawn.
key_stories.outcome: Model finished (~670 tris); animations and behavior scripting still pending.
key_stories.key_quote: He has to be a Wiggler because he gets angry… then he’ll run off and spawn a star.

open_questions.context: Model completed, but animations and final logic (anger states, run path, star spawn) are still undefined.
questions: How many distinct anger states will the Wiggler have?
What specific animations does Zeina plan for each state?
Where exactly will he run and despawn to keep camera and performance clean?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants a hidden Wing Cap on the crane with soft invisible walls preventing out-of-bounds flight.
questions: What final placement method will be used so players understand it’s optional?
How will invisible boundaries be communicated or masked?
Will the cap interact with any red-coin or shortcut challenges?

open_questions.context: Several cuts were made (glass shards, helmet polys) to meet N64 limits.
questions: What is the current per-object and per-scene triangle budget?
How does Kaze profile and verify frame-rate on real hardware?
Are any tools planned to automate poly/CPU budgeting for collaborators?

open_questions.context: Only Up 64 detects EPROM desync but details are sparse.
questions: How reliable is the desync check across common emulators and flashcarts?
Could a false positive soft-lock legit players?
Would he consider open-sourcing or reusing this system in Return to Yoshi’s Island?
